titles.title: Halligen im Sommer bei Ebbe (Halligen in Summer at Low Tide)

makers.displaydate: 1892–1981; born Dithmarschen, Germany; died Heide, Germany
makers.displaymaker: Hans Grohs, 1892–1981; born Dithmarschen, Germany; died Heide, Germany

texts.textentryhtml: After devoting much of his career to narrative woodcuts, often inspired by Nordic myths and biblical stories, Grohs later focused on landscape paintings and watercolors, many of which depict Germany’s northernmost coastal region. Here he evokes one of the sparsely populated Halligen Islands, where the houses are built on top of human-made mounds called Warften that keep the structures safe from flooding. Grohs inserts a dramatic element into the becalmed setting, using cascading layers and small touches of white gouache, an opaque watercolor, in the sky and ocean to suggest an impending apocalyptic storm.

Collection of the artist; by descent to Frauken Grohs Collinson (artist's daughter), 1981; by descent to Rose Mary McKinney (artist's  granddaughter), 2018; gifted to Princeton University Art Museum, 2023.
